unnormalised: The other day, I needed to deposit some cash into my account at SBI, the State Bank of India. I had a cheque for ₹12,500 from a freelancing gig and another ₹5000 in cash from selling some old books online. Usually, I transfer everything digitally via UPI, but this time, the client insisted on a cheque, and the online bookseller preferred cash.
normalised: The other day, I needed to deposit some cash into my account at S-B-I, the State Bank of India. I had a cheque for rupee twelve thousand five hundred from a freelancing gig and another rupee five thousand in cash from selling some old books online. Usually, I transfer everything digitally via U-P-I, but this time, the client insisted on a cheque, and the online bookseller preferred cash.

unnormalised: Reaching the bank on a Tuesday afternoon felt like navigating a mini-mela. The queue for the teller was easily 15 people deep. I took a seat, observing the scene. An elderly gentleman was carefully counting ₹2000 notes he was withdrawing, making sure he had the correct amount - exactly Rs. 10,000, he muttered. A young woman was trying to figure out how to fill a deposit slip for ₹3,750.50.
normalised: Reaching the bank on a Tuesday afternoon felt like navigating a mini-mela. The queue for the teller was easily fifteen people deep. I took a seat, observing the scene. An elderly gentleman was carefully counting rupee two thousand notes he was withdrawing, making sure he had the correct amount - exactly rupee ten thousand, he muttered. A young woman was trying to figure out how to fill a deposit slip for rupee three thousand seven hundred and fifty point five zero.

unnormalised: Finally, my turn came. I handed over the cheque and the cash along with the deposit slip. The teller, a weary-looking man, punched in the details. "Cheque for Rs. 12,500 and cash for Rs. 5000, total Rs. 17,500, right?" he confirmed. I nodded. He then proceeded to verify my ID, asking for my PAN card. Thankfully, I had a copy in my wallet.
normalised: Finally, my turn came. I handed over the cheque and the cash along with the deposit slip. The teller, a weary-looking man, punched in the details. "Cheque for rupee twelve thousand five hundred and cash for rupee five thousand, total rupee seventeen thousand five hundred, right?" he confirmed. I nodded. He then proceeded to verify my I-D, asking for my P-A-N card. Thankfully, I had a copy in my wallet.

unnormalised: He processed the transaction, handing me back the stamped deposit slip. The slip showed the transaction ID and the date, 22/10/2024. Feeling relieved, I stepped away from the counter, ready to brave the Mumbai traffic again.
normalised: He processed the transaction, handing me back the stamped deposit slip. The slip showed the transaction I-D and the date, twenty second october two thousand and twenty four. Feeling relieved, I stepped away from the counter, ready to brave the Mumbai traffic again.

unnormalised: It struck me how much we still rely on these physical transactions, despite the rise of digital payments. Especially for larger amounts or when dealing with older generations, cash and cheques continue to be the norm. Whether it's paying a vendor in ₹500 notes or depositing a cheque for ₹1 lakh, traditional banking still holds its ground.
normalised: It struck me how much we still rely on these physical transactions, despite the rise of digital payments. Especially for larger amounts or when dealing with older generations, cash and cheques continue to be the norm. Whether it's paying a vendor in rupee five hundred notes or depositing a cheque for rupee one lakh, traditional banking still holds its ground.

unnormalised: Later that evening, I checked my online account balance, just to be sure. The deposit was reflected accurately, showing a credit of Rs. 17500. It's good to have options – UPI, cards, cash, cheques – depending on the situation and preference. But that SBI trip definitely reaffirmed that cash is still king, at least in certain pockets of India.
normalised: Later that evening, I checked my online account balance, just to be sure. The deposit was reflected accurately, showing a credit of rupee seventeen thousand five hundred. It's good to have options – U-P-I, cards, cash, cheques – depending on the situation and preference. But that S-B-I trip definitely reaffirmed that cash is still king, at least in certain pockets of India.
